title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — The Indiana Pacers’ march through the 1998 season was not merely a collection of wins, but a coronation. And on this night at Market Square Arena, it was Reggie Miller who wore the crown, delivering a performance for the ages that left the Sacramento Kings in his wake.

Miller, the sharpshooter with ice in his veins, was simply unguardable. He erupted for a game-high 41 points, a scoring barrage that was as efficient as it was explosive. From his trademark spots beyond the arc and with a series of relentless drives, he dismantled the Kings’ defense piece by piece. Every time Sacramento threatened to close the gap, Miller answered with a dagger, silencing the visitors and igniting the home crowd in a familiar, electrifying rhythm.

While Miller’s brilliance was the headline, the Pacers’ victory was a masterclass in team execution. Point guard Mark Jackson orchestrated the offense with precision, dishing out 13 assists and controlling the tempo. The defensive effort, anchored by Dale Davis’s 14 rebounds, smothered the Kings, holding them to a paltry 92 points.

Sacramento, overwhelmed by the Pacers’ intensity and Miller’s historic night, found little room to operate. Their leading scorer, Mitch Richmond, was limited to 22 points, a testament to the swarming Indiana defense.

The final score, 117-92, was a mere formality. The real story was the 41 points next to Reggie Miller’s name—a number that echoed through the arena and served as a stark reminder that on any given night, a legend can take flight, leaving an indelible mark on the game and carrying his team ever closer to its ultimate goal.
